But as you listen for seconds longer, you hear the undertones of sheer terror ringing through. I haven't felt safe or secure. Much less loved and chosen.

column3: One of the questions was why do I like to wear long sleeves or a jacket even when it's summer?&nbsp
column4: The answer is in two parts. I'm pretty sensitive to air-conditioning and get cold easily, and I like the security I feel when my hands are touching something like the cuffs of a jacket. I feel more confident and less awkward when I'm standing talking to someone cause I can put my hands in the pocket of my jacket and it's a relaxed non-threatening pose. Crossing your arms can be misinterpreted and putting your hands in pants pockets can feel weird and can be misread also. &nbsp
column5:

Ever since I was little I had my baby blanket (still do actually!) that went pretty much everywhere with me, and at least was always in my bed at night. event,"Some really amazing things have been happening over this brief period of silence. Ya I know...brief like the intertestimonial period.
Anyways... Some sweet things like mom getting done with cancer treatment in July, me surviving my sophomore year of college, finding a great church and amazing community, giving my life to Christ for real, stepping out of years of sinful patterns, experiencing Grace like never before along with forgiveness, Love, mercy, and acceptance. My niece Kathryn Rose (Kati) was born July 5th, I got to come back to Asbury for my Junior year, I'm learning to play cello, I got to play french horn for a few of the services at Quest (and it was Awesome!!!), and got to restore a few friendships.
Some pretty nasty things have happened as well. I willingly picked old patterns again that caused more pain, mom developed a large tumor very rapidly and had to have surgery and deal with complications, tumor was diagnosed containing stage one ovarian cancer, in removing said tumor found more small bowel cancer from last year (We are still in the middle of all that stay tuned for when chemo starts), got really behind in this semester and am struggling to finish well, and realized I'm struggling with depression.

But that's not why I need to write.

See I met this guy.
Well, the reality is my best friend found me again. It has been a wonderful few months. Getting to experience Love in ways I've only dreamed of. Having him come back after all these years and choose me. To worship together, to read together, pray together, laugh together, dream together....
column2:
My family is so happy. It's perfect. We agree and compromise on everything important...even down to agreeing Peanut Butter must be Jiff. I seriously think we are about 20 steps ahead of most couples when they are first married.

And.....

Jesus is asking us to give it to Him in a true sacrifice. To walk away from everything "
column3: perfect&quot
column4:
. To trust Him so deeply that we give back what He's given us. To raise the knife above our dearest relationship and at the very least begin to drop it. Everything that we have both desired, dreamed for, wished for, prayed for, thought was lost- is right in front of us and Jesus is asking us to Trust Him and walk away.
I can't begin to describe for you the pain this is causing my heart. I know this is what Jesus is asking.
column5:
Jesus is calling me into a time with just Him. A time where He can call me into the desert and betroth me unto Himself in righteousness and faithfulness. (Hosea 2) I can see God's faithfulness in this and can recount many examples of where He has walked it out and proven himself faithful. However sacrifice isn't really sacrifice unless there is pain. This is refining. It is going to change me and change him. I want it and want to run from it at the very same instant. I can't control my life. I want to, but I can't.
That's why my Quest family is saying anyways.

Mostly everyone else is so totally in support of it all it's crazy. My family absolutely loves him and won't take anything different. My nieces and nephews love spending time with him along with my sister and her husband. He is prolly the only guy in the world my brother will take a second glance at because he was friends with my brother long before I was. I'm realizing each day just how much I do love him. column1:
event,"There is a huge lump in my chest made up of all my thoughts, feelings, emotions, actions, images...everything. And it's stuck. Something happened today and I can't stop replaying it over and over in my head only this time saying and doing what I wished I would have been quick and brave enough to do the first time. Don't worry no one died. No one got hurt....well. I guess that is up to your definition of hurt.

But in order for me to share this burden I have to be a ""psycho"" and fill you in on the ""why"" and care more about that than the ""what."" (FYI ""Psycho"" is the loving joking term my mom says about me when we refer to me being a psych major :-D )

Why does the why matter? well because telling you that they wouldn't let my mom keep her shoes on going through the airport security doesn't share much of my burden does it?

See like I've told you before mom is undergoing cancer treatment in Philly and I went with her this week. It was a good thing to. I figured out per pharmacy's instructions she had been taking her chemo pill incorrectly which is what was causing her sever nausea. There was an immediate difference when she started taking the pill half an hour after her meal instead of during it. And I got her through the surgery to insert her chemo port.
column2: Anyway..... she spends a week at the center. It's an amazing place. Everyone strives to know your name and everyone and I mean everyone that passes you looks you in the eye, smlies and says hello. The atmosphere is calm and relaxed. Everything is at your own pace. You aren't an inconvince no matter what. There are snacks and water everywhere...even in the shuttle vans and the cars that pick you up from the airport. You are surrounded by people who understand because they are there! The fellow patients know when you need a hug and when you can't stand being touched. They care. It's what they have. I was amazed at these patients. They are all going through treatments but they look out for one another. They encourage, pray with, cry with, smile with you. You are in control there but you are pampered to the gills. It's humbling really.&nbsp
column3:
i'll get into my thoughts more later but this is about today....
This is where we spent our week. Finally the white stretch limo pulled up and we packed our stuff to go home. The driver loaded our luggage and opened the doors. When we pulled up to the airport he opened the doors and set our luggage on the curb. And left.

We weren't in Kansas anymore.

We were surrounded by people. We went up to the touch screen check in kiosk to print off our tickets and it said there was an error...no seats. What!?!?
column4: Mom started getting flustered. She talked to the woman behind the desk who was also stressed and a little confused due to all the things she was trying to handle at once God bless her. We finally got our tickets they just weren't together which was the computers problem.&nbsp
column5: So we move on to the security check point.&nbsp
column6:
Now for the last week or so mom has finally decided not to take off her shoes and just asks to be searched personally with their wand. It's because of the meds shes on for chemo causes her to have neuropathy in her hands and feet. She takes herbs so there isn't constant pain but she says her appendages feel like they are always going to sleep. Adding on her weakness putting on shoes is a trying task. She puts them on in the morning and doesn't take them off until she goes to bed. Even then some mornings I did it for her or dad does it on weekends. Erie airport has been supportive of this and doesn't mind doing a couple extra steps. Philadelphia on the other hand....
First off they decided to search her little carry on back pack with all her meds in it again. *sigh* Okay. I handled that while mom went over to the side with the attendant. I was getting anxious like I always do going through security and this time I had alot to manange...our coats, my shoes, my backpack, my laptop in a different holder and my carry on suitcase. And now him searching her bag. I was trying to keep my cool.
column7:
Then the TSA agent walked over to my mom who was sitting in a chair and bent over to be more in her face and told her basically ( i oculdn't hear everything) that next time she flew she must, she MUST take off her shoes. It was the rule and everyone had to follow it. I tried to explain why she couldn't and she kept cutting me off and said that she could she just wouldn't. The way she handled it...it was a power trip.

Don't get me wrong, I totally respect security and understand the strictness and severity of their job. As we were waiting for the limo at the center I caught an article in the paper about things like alligators, snacks, and tarantulas people had tried to sneak loose past check point so they could have them on the plane!! I'm thankful for the checkpoint. However there are exceptions to every rule. My mom was a trooper though, she held firm and didn't cry because she knew it was a power trip. I was afraid to go further thinking that she could have me taken my security for ""harassing her"" and then we'd miss the flight. I wanted to ask her to talk to me somewhere quiet so we could talk...or ask for her supervisor but I didn't want to make a scene and make things worse.
column8: On top of this mom gets really anxious at airports ever since her first trip back to Erie when she fell asleep in the terminal and missed her flight. Sure they called her name over the loudspeaker, but no one physically came over and asked her if she needed to board.
column9:
Every friday once dad picks her up and takes her somewhere to eat, at some point she just breaks down crying. Now I understand why. Once you step out of that car and enter the airport it's a whole new world. People don't know about her. Frankly they don't care. She has business men flying by her in suits, kids running around her ankles, Loud noises, fast paced..strict and cold compared to the center. It's traumatic. Now adding the TSA agents on top of it.... it's crushing. Her anxiety rises the min she steps out of the car and doesn't calm down until her body can't handle it anymore at home.

Tomorrow I'm going to try to find the airport super in charge of security and try to figure out how to handle mom's situation better. I want to follow the rules I appreciate the rules. I want to handle this through the proper chain of authority I just have to figure out what that is. Up till this point it's been at the check point asking for exception. I guess we need something more.
column10:
If the airport itself doesn't work I'll call her case manager at the center and ask if she can write up a note for her. This feels so high school on some levels but it's okay. If you had a doc. appointment you were excused but you couldn't just up and walk out, you had to turn in the excuse and sign out. I'm okay with that....
All night I keep going over the situation and thinking over what I would have said. I keep thinking about what I hope to say tomorrow. But it's hard. I can't just say my mom can't take off her shoes. To those who aren't experiencing the side effects and the anxiety she is, it's a stupid suspisious request. It's just taking off your shoes.... you do it all the time. It's quick.... but for mom it's not. I just have to bait the person on the other line long enough to understand that.

I hate security check points anyway. My fear of screwing up comes flying at me. I feel like the atmosphere is one of hostility.... hurry up...don't mess up....don't make a scene....hurry up....you look like a fool why can't you get your shoe on..... calm down you might look suspicious.....
column11: &nbsp
column12:
I know it's weird. But true. My mom and I are alot alike...I can see the same fears reflected in her eyes that are resounding in my head. We have alot in common....

People at the center say we have the same smile......






I did it though. I got really scared/nervous the night before. I panicked. I was afraid I couldn't do it. I was afraid I would get there and fall apart half way through the week and let her down. But I didn't. The first day or so I felt pretty much useless at the center. She had her routine and I didn't know anything. Except she was still incredibly nauseous.
column13: The cool thing was the radiation guys were really kind and took me in and showed me how the machine worked and I got to watch the computer as they did the scan and the treatment. It was awesome!! Monday night mom had another break down..... when we got back to the apartment we both laid down and took a nap since we'd been up since 5am and flying to philly. We slept for two hours which was a little too long. She woke up and her body was hungry and needed food but by that time she was so tired and weak and nauseous to eat even though that's what she needed. I kept calm and handled it and everything was okay. Thankfully on tuesday I figured out her medicine fiasco so she felt much better for her surgery thankfully. I know that would have been a disaster if she had been so nauseous still. I did what needed to be done and it was awesome. I love the adreneline that kicks in when I have something important that needs to be done NOW. I loved thinking about what she needed. Thinking enough to arrange a car to take us home after radiation was complete the day of her surgery so she wouldn't have to wait longer and deal with the bumpy shuttle. I love being close enough to my mom to read her and know what she needs. She calls me her drug pusher :-D&nbsp
column14:
I handled thinking through things she couldn't, talking to important people, and just being there when she needed to cry. She needed me this week. And I showed up. That is satisfying.

Leading up to this week my aunt, who went with her last week for the short week, kept telling me that my role was comic relief..keeping things light. When when the rubber met the road that was like strapping david into saul's armor. It wasn't my role. That was her role last week for sure but My role was supporter. Burden carrier, understander, compassionate friend. This was the longest week of treatment she'd had and she was scared going into it. She didn't think she could handle it. My job is to remind her to take it one step at a time and to praise her when she took as step. This week actually turned out really well and flew pretty quickly. We have the strongest bond in this because she was there with me when I went through my surgeries and had to face the fear of the unknown, the uncomfortable, and return to know dreaded known. She leans on me to reveal the secrets of how I did it. It was my job to be patient with her. To be her time keeper. To think ahead and relieve potential problems before they got out of hand.
column15:
And amazingly.... I was successful. To me that is humbling and astounding.

Right now she is troubled about her port. She can't handle having it there right now knowing it's going to stay for about six months. I was trying to encourage her by telling her it was cool and hey at least it will come out. In all honesty I was just trying to be positive that it was going to come out eventually but she replied.... yeah, that's true yours don't huh? Ouch. I didn't mean it like that..but it's true. Her implant is for a short time, daunting as it is. My rods are there ..always. I can't escape. There is no countdown to removal. Hmm.
column16:
It just pangs me to think she prolly thinks this port makes her less human or something. To me it makes her beautiful. I'm so proud of her. This hasn't been easy at all and she is doing so well. Not perfectly of course but doing well. Amazingly well. I'm so proud and honored to call her Mom. *misty eyes*

Next week Corey is going with her for the week. This is good but doesn't solve the airport problems due to the way Philly airport is set up they have to go through different check points. I hope this goes okay. I hope he swallows himself and serves her. I hope it's good for them. She protects him, babies him, he's a boy so he isn't expected to do certain things. Especially things not included in the masculine role. It's always been this way. I hope he won't let her this time. I hope he thinks ahead and is her caregiver not her son. I hope he won't let her do things like tie her shoes when she shouldn't or rearrange the furniture or carry her purse..... I hope he'll let her cry like she needs to...I hope she lets her self cry like she needs too.
column17:
I hope he proves to be the man I know is hiding in him somewhere. ..... I hope she doesn't forget me.....



I don't know how to describe myself right now. I'm not anxious in the sense of shaking, higher alertness, or the tapping of my fingers together darting my eyes around like I do.... I'm not stressed like I'm going to explode like there is a pressure building or something... but I can't relax.
column19: Why is it that the things I'm so very good at, the things I feel alive about I'm so good at that I doing them for any length of time would kill me? I love taking care of people physically, mentally, emotionally, and even spiritually as weak as that is right now. I am a defender. I am truly a caretaker. At the beginning of the week it was the nametag that I didn't feel comfortable wearing... I couldn't be mom's caretaker..I'm the baby girl... her baby girl. But ask the week went on I'm beginning to understand just how true that title is. It's been one of my downfalls in relationships. I pave the way..I make everything smooth. Basically treat them perfectly and meet their every need, wish, hope, dream that I could possibly do. It set the tone of them being taken care of.... when when that would change and I exhausted myself and it felt like something was missing from the relationship and when I needed them to take care of me they wouldn't know how, and I wouldn't know how to let them....or I smothered them and they ran away.&nbsp
column20:
Maybe I'm blowing this up and making it bigger than it is....but I feel like it's happening again and it pains me.

I feel like people are my biggest strength and my biggest weakness.

Three girls were stabbed to death because their mother thought they were demon possessed. Social work and family services had been called in many times leading up to this. The school started an investigation when it was believed the mother was holding the oldest captive from school. It was closed when they couldn't find the family. Now they are all dead.
I want to be a rescuer. I want to meet someone on a dangerous road and help them steer a different direction to safety. The problem? Failure isn't an option and that isn't always in my control.
column21:
But I can't get away from somethings....like I care more about the why than the what.

I leave for school 4am sunday morning. My flight out of pittsburgh leaves at 7am for Louisville. am I ready? not yet.

I need a hug. One where they hug you and you let go and stop running and melt. I need a daddy hug but hugs from my dad hurt....his body shape doesn't go with mine and it hurts. My brother's hugs are empty and fleeting. My significant other's are more taking than giving which is what they need right now as they are really sick.
column22:
I don't trust anyone else that much to let myself stop and let go. I don't want anyone to get attached. I don't want to do something I'll regret in a weak moment.... I don't want to relax and then have to start fighting again. I just want to be put to sleep and have someone stay up standing guard protecting me. Why is that something I feel I must have?

As the airplane was taxiing off the runway out of philly I looked out the window and told God i believed in him I just didn't know what to do with that or where to find him right now.

This is the whirlwind that is me.

But soon I'll be back to my routine...class, work, cheer, sleep, repeat. It worked well last semester look at my GPA for goodness sake!! But do I have the strength to keep going?

Fake it till you make it I suppose. Either do or do not there is no try.
"

column1:
event,"Wow here we are....2008....weird.

Mom decided to go alone. Time kinda ran out in a way and the last we had talked she said she wanted me to stay.
I spent New Year's Eve with Alyssa and some of our friends. Two of them got married during the early evening. I was a little bit...apprehensive you could say about this wedding but it turned out really elegant. We were there for about six hours! I even got to dance. Heck yes!! After the wedding Alyssa and I went back to her house to change and got into a much needed conversation. It's been hard to stay close while
column2: I'm away at school and sometimes little things pile up making the road pretty cluttered. We both had things we needed to confess in order to clear the street. But we did and it was a time of confession and understanding not resentment and blame. The night went even better after that even though not much happened. One of our friends came back to her house and we played Tony Hawk on her new PS2 until five min. till midnight, found a TV station and watched the ball drop at midnight. We toasted sparkling white grape juice and popped in a movie. We only made it about half way through when her parents got home and we decided we were half asleep anyway we might as well go to bed. During the night we got a light covering of snow. We spent New Year's Day pretty much not doing much of anything. We slept in, made food, watched TV, read books, took a nap...etc etc. It was really relaxed. During our time of relaxation and rest we failed to realize that the snow that had begun during the night had refused to let up. We got like eight inches!! By the time we realized it, it was after dinner and the sun had already gone down. It was pretty much too late for me to go home. So Unfortunatly I haven't seen my mom yet this year. (tee hee...sounds so much worse than it is. Really it's that I haven't seen her in a day) After we made dinner we went over to our friend's house to finish the movie we started and play more video games...this time on his Xbox 360. We were having so much fun we didn't leave till about 3am!! It was time well spent. He is leaving tomorrow to go to school in Florida so it was the last time we'll see him in a while. We got a couple hours of sleep and then alyssa had to go into work for a couple hours this morning. She actually got some overtime because the other cashier got into a car accident......yeah the snow is that bad..... I got up and cleaned off her car while she got a quick shower. When she left I ate breakfast and finished the book I had started while I was there. Then I took my nap :-) This was at about eight am mind you I deserved it!!&nbsp
column3: Today has pretty much been spent like the last couple before it. Reading, sleeping, video games, TV, food....and just chillin out with my best friend. We came back to my house and watched the first couple episodes of NCIS with my dad. She decided she wanted to know what all my fuss has been about the show for all this time!! It's such a good show. Then we played a video game we picked up tonight and now she is getting some sleep before she has to drive home in the morning for work.
column4: You may be wondering why I'm not sleeping yet either....... and that my friend....is what I'm asking myself. It was surprisingly easy to get up even that early this morning and I got a lot accomplished before I took a nap. I only slept for a couple hours before I got up and got my shower and I've been pretty much awake the rest of the day....I guess I did have a short nap but hey. But I'm still awake. I may even try a bit of Spyro before I turn in.
column5:
Alyssa and I have also started reading a book called ""The Looking Glass Wars"" (I think that's the title.) It's really good so far...I read the first eleven chapters this afternoon. :-D I think the bookworm-ness of my roommate is starting to rub off a little. *smiles*
It's pretty much a book saying that Lewis Caroll's version of Alice in Wonderland was all wrong and this is the true story of Alyss Heart Princess of Wonderland and the ranging war with her Aunt Redd. Good fantasy.

So even though I got an amazing GPA this semester....I'm still not ready to go back. It's too soon. Even after the past few days of chillin out i still have stress knots that haven't been worked out all over my body. I've loved the last couple days. I would love to stay here and find a nice little job...maybe working at that coffee shop I visited last week. But no. Come monday I leave for Philly then back to KY where my schedule still isn't worked out and I'm still not sure how I'm getting there. I've tried to fix it on line but it's still reading me as an underclassmen and won't let me registar for the upperlevel classes I need and earned. *sigh* It doesn't help that this semester we start bright and early monday morning instead of tuesday like it's been the last three semesters I've been there. That really makes things difficult. The book store isn't open on sundays. And as of right now I have an eight am monday class. Yay Me. It also doesn't thrill me that most of my classes will be with one of the few people on campus at this point I don't want to see or be near. I've been burned again and again and it's my fault for being like a mesquito to a bug zapper and i'd rather not repeat this again but we have the same major thus must take the same classes for the majority of our time spent until we graduate. *sigh* What sucks is I have so many questions that I feel should be answered and I'm drawn to find those answers. But it's too late. Even though it matters to me, in the whole situation they don't matter. It's gone. Their gone. I need to accept it and let the actions be all the answers I need. Maybe someday I'll be able to be around them without wanting to cry, scream, or slam them against the wall. Someday I'll be able to pass them with no overloading of memories...maybe I'll pass them with no recognition to me at all..... just like what happens when they walk by me.

.........sorry, I guess I needed to get that out........


As for the rest of this week....not sure. I feel like a juggler tossing a few possiblities in the air. I guess as each day comes we'll find out which stay in my hand and which fall to the ground.

column1: event,"<font color=""#800080""><i>I sit in a coffee shop wonderfully taking a break from the speed of life. I really enjoy this little place close to where I live. It's got dark wood walls, amazing black and white art around, japanese lanterns for lighting...it's just really calming. It's nice to sit with my laptop, my roommate across from me and take time to rest. Just be. Right now I don't have any responsibility over anyone or anything. There is nothing I must have compleated by any certain time. No performing, no pleasing, no need to strike up my brain to keep conversations lively. Just me. If I have something to say to Val, I say it and vice versa. I love that I have this right now. I love that it's okay to sit at the same table and read a book.&nbsp
column2:
Silence can be very bonding sometimes.

So to fill you in on break....

I finished my finals, Alyssa came down and picked me up. We loaded our stuff and left the wonderful world of Asbury behind. Once I got home it started. I had about a day before we went to pick up mom. I was really impresesd that the house was in a really good order when I got home. Things were clean and put away.
column3: When dad and I went to the airport to get mom her flight was delayed for about an hour. Dad and I went to the mall and starbucks to kill time. He even tried my ""coffee"" and said ""It's not bad""&nbsp
column4:
from my dad...that's amazing. He's a dy hard black truck stop coffee kinda guy. When we went back to the airport her flight had been delayed even further! As we waited this woman came over and asked if we were waiting for someone or waiting to leave. We answered her questions but were cautious until we could figure out if she was from the Airport, or just some overly-friendly stranger! Turns out she was a local reporter for the news station and wondered if we would talk to her on camera!!! It was really cool seeing as how my brother made it on the news in N.C. for skipping class and playing golf on a really warm day! I figured they were doing a story on the delays at the airport but our story ended up being the whole story. :-) It was awesome!! It made time pass a bit better.

It was a bit of an adjustment having mom home. Since she had undergone her first full week of treatments she was pretty worn out. The side effects are really hitting her hard. The first morning she was home she came up into my room, sat on my bed and just started crying. It ripped my heart out! I didn't know what to do except hug her...so i did. I was amazed though at the strength I found when i needed it though. It hurt but it also gave me strength and power to be there. I know she leans on me because I've been there. I know she relys on my messages somedays to help get her through. I'm trying to remember to send them to her :-) She's had to watch me go through the unknown of surgery...and then turn around and face it all over again knowing what was going to happen. I think that is why I can handle this to the degree that I can. (not saying that's a tremendously strong degree but it's a degree none the less) because I've been there I know, I understand the fears, the struggles, the feeling like crap and powerless to do anything about it. I am really proud of her. She amazes me.
I spent that morning trying to figure out what to do with mom to help her feel better. So we went shopping :-) It was a really amazing time spent with mom. We came up with some really good present Ideas and were able to compleate both of our lists. Shortly after we got home my brother and his girlfriend arrived from the south.

On sunday after church and lunch we decided to go ice skating. Even the kids came with us!! That was amazing. My Sister and her family, Mom, dad, Corey, Christy, me and alyssa all went skating. Everyone skated except bridget, herb, sam (the youngest child) and dad.
column5:
Yup that means even mom went on the ice!! It was a blast teaching the kids how to skate. All three were kinda timid to start but by the end Cammi and Ben had found a support ""chair"" thing that you can hold onto to help keep your balance and were flying around on their own. Afterwards I got to go and hang out with alyssa.

Christmas Eve was good..... Church bothered me a bit, just that I would have organized the service differently and would have picked different hymns personally but it was okay. I guess it's hard coming back year after year to the same place and watching it change each year remembering better times, and worse times. Christmas Eve has always been more important to me than Christmas day. It was the day of celebration. It was the height of the waiting of advent. Everything was decorated,
column6: happy people were everywhere. Everyone was relaxed with this feeling that they had made it, they had arrived. It was time to celebrate!!&nbsp
column7: This year it didn't feel like that.... it felt like people would there because it was ritual, you could see on their faces the millions of things going through their mind of things that needed to be finished before the dawn of Christmas morning. Maybe it's just cause I'm not a lilttle child anymore.&nbsp
column8: Our open house went well though. I love playing hostess. I even got to play guitar with a man in our church. I hope I get to do that again before I leave. He's great. He's an older man that reminds me alot of John.....whom I really hope to see before I leave as well!!
column9:
I decided to wear my black dress for the evening service. It made me feel amazing

Christmas day.... eh..yeah.
column10: the kids (by that I include my sister and her husband as well) all showed up in the morning for breakfast and to open presents. My brother was being a dork as usual. The nice change was my dad stuck up for me and silenced him. :-D Bridget even threw in her charge to quit later. It made me smile.&nbsp
column11: The opening of the presents was a little stressful...my mom paniced a bit about picture taking and commading me to do certain things. But we survived. It was a nice simple Christmas. The really cool thing was my mom got all of us alternative gifts. She had made donations for different causes in honor of us. Each was to something close to our hearts. My dad's was for aid to Vietnamese Children, Mine was for eye care and surgery overseas, Christy's was for medical supplies in Bolivia and Corey's was towards the Raleigh Ringers. Wow...that kinda sounds like Corey doesn't care about helping matters overseas but that really isn't the case! Lol. That was a donation that is personal to him since he rang with them for a year....and that's what my mom chose lol.&nbsp
column12: After lunch time the kids left for their other grandparents and we got cozy and watched Christy's christmas present from corey.....Finding Nemo :-D&nbsp
column13: The rest of the day we just kinda chilled out. It was really good to have mom home though. She told us there were alot of patients that couldn't leave. Their treatments are literally fighting for their lives. Wow. ......just wow. I'm looking forward to spending the week with her there.....and honestly..scared out of my mind. Truly.&nbsp
column14:
I'm looking forward to hearing people's stories though. Mom says there are some amazing people there.

The day after Christmas Mom and aunt susie flew back to philly for treatment again.
column15: Dad and I had to go later in the day for my annual eye appointment. This was going to be the moment of truth. I've been out of my glasses since the beginning of summer and now it was time to test my eyes to see if it was a good choice. I've been able to do pretty well. There are some new obstacles but I've adapted really well.&nbsp
column16: I can't read small print as well as I could with glasses and sometimes i don't see things in my periphial vision unless I cognitavly focus on it but i've been award of this and remember to look around. I was hoping that I could just walk in, tell them my eyes were great and leave....but no they wanted to dialate them anyway and take a look. *sigh*&nbsp
column17: I've been having my eyes dialated since I was like 11 months old. It gets old after a while!! lol&nbsp
column18: it's also hard to have an appointment were you are rendered incapable to drive afterwards!&nbsp
column19: Anyways, It really threw me having my eyes dialated without my glasses. The dialation makes everything really fuzzy and blurry and makes me really sensitive to light. Having my glasses helps things stay a tough more in focus....not a lot though. Not having my glasses threw my brain for a loop and I could feel it starting to stress trying to keep focused. I started getting a headache. I finally put on my sunglasses and everything calmed down. My brain is such a funny child. When they did the exam he determined....drum roll please..... my eyes have gotten even stronger since being out of glasses!!!! Whoooot. That is really a continuation of a miracle. That wasn't ""supposed to happen.""&nbsp
column20: After my appoitment was finished dad wanted to go to the mall and get his hair cut.&nbsp
column21: Once he signed up we had about a 45 min. wait so we walked around and got ice cream. It was soooo good. It's a good thing you don't need to see to taste. :-D&nbsp
column22: While he was getting his hair cut I went next door into Steve and Berry's which carries mostly screen printed shirts and other clothing sporting teams logos.&nbsp
column23: They were having a really good sale (The sign was big enough I could read it :-D) I was just walking around for the fun of it and I saw these amazing dress pants and a really cute sweater. But I couldn't read the sizes!!&nbsp
column24: Once dad was finished I brought him over and he helped me It was a cute bonding moment. I took two sizes of pants in two different colors. The grey ones were too small so I asked dad to get the other size. It was when he brought them to me that I finally realized they had pin stripes. &gt
column28:
I ended up getting grey and black dress pants and the sweater. Because of the sale the total for all three was less than a pair of pants elsewhere. Whoooot. I'm glad dad helped too. He was so cute about it.
The other amazing thing that happend on Wednesday....my grades came for this semester....... Drum roll....my semester GPA was.......3.81!!!!!!
column32: Oh man that is amazing. I'm so happy I worked hard all semester and finished strong. I was a little worried about that that my finals wouldn't be great. But I guess they were awesome. I had one B+, One A- and the rest were A's.&nbsp
column33: That is so much better than my first semester GPA of 2.31. or something low like that. So now my cumalative is 3.01 (what's with the .o1???) Which should be enough to apply for the internship at WKU over the summer for research. Whoot.&nbsp
column35: The Cherry on the milkshake came with two little words at the bottom of the page.&nbsp
column114: Whoa. Me. Homeschool slacker....surgery girl.....the one with a horrible first semester..... worked hard, learned self discipline..... and Made deans list.&nbsp
column115: It makes me want to cry. I got so excited I called my mom and left her a message.&nbsp
column118: Yeah I walked on air the rest of the day.&nbsp

Alyssa and I tried to just chill out but we both got bored...so we invented a game. Pretty simple really..... We basically just went up one escalater and went down the other as many times as we good.
column159: Mind you both escalaters are side by side. Yeah we were bored. There was a woman ringing the salvation army bell at the top...she got on about the 5th time.&nbsp

column163: The rest of the day was spent navigating Pittsburgh, almost dying a few times, getting lost a few times, screaming and laughing..... and going two hours late to a party. Yes. Good times.&nbsp
column164:
Alyssa stayed the night with us and we got to play ps2 games until we all fell asleep.

Val and I got up this morning and went to the gym. She needed to swim and I went to work out. Turns out we were an hour too soon for the pool so we went through her weight lifting routine together. It was a blast!!
column166: Once the hour was up she swam and I continued doing some other lifting excersises and walked the track. I feel so good!!&nbsp
column167:
After our two hours we came back to the house and played more video games with alyssa after we fixed lunch.

Now We are sitting in the coffee shop while alyssa is working. She'll be done really soon and we'll go back and prolly play more games and sleep. We take val back tomorrow morning. Yay more Pittsburgh tee hee.

I feel like this is the point in the entry where I release the amazing poetry that bounces around in my brain. However any lyrics that may be in there....are still non english and still await translation. Sorry.

I still don't quite know how I am. I know I'm stressed. I'm quick to get loud. Things frustrate me. Right now there is a choke in my throat as I try to figure out how I am. I want to cry. But it's deep inside...no where near the surface.
column168: I did cry when my relationship with my brother took a step back again though. I hate it. I hate that I only have a brother in practicality. Not in practice. I hate that I can't get away from it either. No matter what I do he is the only person in the world who has my DNA. He's my brother. Why is it so hard for him to act like it?&nbsp
column169: I don't know anything worth knowing about him. And he doesn't know me. I've tried to not care but I do. But I also know that it's up to him.&nbsp
column170:
What hurts is that I know that he knows there is something wrong with it. I know he knows alot of it is on his end....he's told me. But words are as far as it has gotten. Actions are stlil lacking. Some people put family at the top of the totem pole... I however am at the bottom of his. Will it ever change?
It's also so difficult trying to balance out how to do things in a way to make people has happy as possible. Not that I'm overly trying to please people...but trying to come to a solution that works the best for everyone. Sometimes it works....sometimes not so much.
I also can't find a rhythm to all this yet. Every day has been an exception. I can't believe I'm saying this but I miss routine. Val and I had a solid routine at school. Now everything is different and exceptions are everywhere. It makes it hard to plan activities with people.

I need to practice my french horn.

I'm doing okay with my mom I think.... it's still hard to see her in pain or spaz out about nothing. But I noticed her way of asking for help..... Some people ask polietly... ""Will you please open this for me?""
column171: Others cut the formality and get right to the point.."" Open this""&nbsp
column172: Mom however...makes it your honor to help her.&nbsp
column174:
When we were out on our shopping adventure we stopped at subway to eat. She got a choc. milk and couldn't open the cap. She passed it to me and said that I could open it. I smiled and a memory played through my mind of walking into an elevator and hearing mom say I could push the button. That's what this felt like. And that is what is important to me. I am honored to be there to open her choc. milk when she can't. That's how I have to look at all this. If I don't, someone else will. I want this honor. *smiles*

Life is an honor.

column2:
Seeing as this is finals week of my fall semester sophomore year, I thought it might be approriate to update this seeing as how my last post was regarding the first week of classes!!

It's been a good semester i think. Very challenging. Very different.
I did actually join the cheerleading squad!! Check that out!! There are six amazing girls. We aren't your normal squad that's for sure. We've all been through alot already but hopefully next semester we can start stunting. Don't worry I'm not one that gets thrown in the air....I'm one that does the throwing *winks*
Let's see.... the people I was having ""communication issues"" at the start of the semester...yeah that's pretty much the same. Lol. I've tried a bit, they've tried a bit and it just keeps blowing up. Someday I'll learn to just walk away and never look back.

My classes have been alot easier than I thought they were going to which gives me serious hope for next semester!! I had a perfect grade in Math for a few weeks!! I was even ranked first in the class (!!!!!) Yup little psych major is good at math. Who knew?? (The streak came to an end for reasons which I will disclose later)
column3: Latin has been alot of fun. Not your normal language class that's for sure! My prof. is also our sophomore class adviser. I'm really glad I've had a chance to get to know him better. He's a wonderful guy. I did end up doing Gen Psych II and handbells at the same time. I even got credit for both!! YAY I love amazing profs.&nbsp
column4: Handbells has been pretty much perfect. I'm ringing E6, F6, which given the change to have picked...is excactly where I wanted to be. For the first half of the semester my roommate val was on one side of me and my other really good friend Brittany was on the other side. Perfection!!&nbsp
column5: We lost a ringer or so about half way through and had to do some reassigning of bell parts so Val is further down the table...But I still have Brit!...and Mary Ann who has been an endless source of entertainment since she found out I'm Corey's sister.&nbsp
column6: :-)&nbsp
column7: I took my Philosophy and Latin finals today. Tomorrow is Social Psych and Math 120. The rest of my classes either I didn't have a final (Like bells) or I took it already. (Gen Psych Post test) I ended up dropping fitness walking. Having an 8am class followed by a huge chunk from 10-1, then another class at 2, followed by 8:45-10:45pm cheer practice.....was brutal!! I wasn't getting anything done in the evening because by the time dinner rolled around I was exhausted and needed to take a nap just to survive cheering. Making the Squad will give me the one credit PE credit I needed anyway soooo bye bye fitness walking.&nbsp
column8:
I had two papers assigned this semester. Both of which were written at at the latest one day before the due date, handed in one time, and one was even at the maximum of length assigned. Booya!!

My comments in the last post about being different
column9: regarding personality, have proved to be true. I've been alot different this semester. I've gone to classes and cheered. That's pretty much it!! It took me until cheerleading to even really get me out of the room to start with. I just don't want to be around people lately. I'm not the same person I was and I don't know quite how to wear that around other people yet.... espeically people who I don't think would agree with the changes. Some people have sought me out and I've responded warmly so it's not like I'm turning into an old hag!! I'm just not seeking others out.&nbsp
column10:
Val and I have been great though. We've had a lot of deep meaningful conversations through out this semester that I hope continue into the future. She really has been the perfect roommate for me right now. She hasn't let me dissapear compleatly into total hiding, but has also encouraged me that I don't have to be around everyone all the time. She has also been amazingly understanding and knowledgable in another serious area of my life......

There have been alot of things that happened this semester. My cousin got married and I was able to travel to their wedding in September. It was so beautiful!!
column11: My mom was able to go but she was really sick. See, she'd been having problems with her stomach since June or July. Started out annoying and kept getting worse. By the time the wedding rolled around the end of sept. she was in serious pain and on an all liquid diet. They kept trying to test other areas like gall bladder and stupid stuff like that. No luck.&nbsp
column12: She took this medicine so they could do a scan and weeks later some of the meds were still inside!! That's how badly her digestive system had shut down. They finally scheduled a date for surgery to figure out what was wrong. (They thought originally that parts of her small intestine were twisted weird) When they did the surgery they found a tumor compleatly blocking her small intestine which had caused the whole system to shut down and her stomach to swell four times its normal size. :-(&nbsp
column13: I was still here when they did the surgery. It was like on a wednesday. On monday they got the test results from the biopsy that the tumor was cancerous. I took the rest of the week off school and borrowed my friends car and drove home. All of my profs were amazing about letting me go. But when I got back I had to take a math test that I thought I was ready for and wasn't actually. I didn't&nbsp
column14: do too poorly on it...just didn't keep my perfect score. I spent the rest of the week home. When I got home on tuesday mom was still really sick. She could barely function. By the time I left she was walking around, joking, laughing and eating!!! :-) Not long after she was able to return home and continue healing. Even though they were able to compleatly remove the tumor there were still spots of cancer cells they found around the area. They took those off as well but it's hard to tell if there are anymore cells waiting to band together. The doctors recommended further treatment as a precaution to prevent anything else from reoccuring. She did alot of research, went through more testing, and decided to go to a Cancer treatment center in Philly.&nbsp
column15:
She will spend 5 weeks in radiation and chemotherapy treatments and then one chemotherapy treatment once every two weeks. She will spend the week in Philly and fly home on the weekends. She started this last week.

The good news is she will be home for Christmas. But in some ways it doesn't make it any easier. She has never handled medicine well and she is already starting to feel the effects from treatments. She'll leave again the day after Christmas.
column16:
I'm planning on going with her the last full week I'm home.

You are prolly wondering how I am right? ..... I don't know.
column17: On one hand I'm really okay. It's something we need to do and once we are done she'll be better. Her life isn't hanging in the balance and there will be a good end to these treatments. She was so amazing in how she showed she was there for me during my surgeries and now it's my turn. I want to go home and be there and give back what I enjoyed from her. I'm looking forward to going through my old homeschool books and picking out some of the books we read then and reading them to her now.&nbsp
column18: When I go home I will have alot more responsiblities in our traditions for Christmas. It will be fun to bake the cookies, decorate the tree, and play hostess on Christmas Eve and make sure everything is good. This is a huge challenge. Break is shorter to begin with, our spring break and our easter break have been combined into one week next year and spring semester is longer. Ohhh joy!!&nbsp
column19:
Now I have the task of making sure mom is as comfortable as possible when she is home for the weekends.

On the other hand I hate it. I can't handle it. It's like the universe has flipped....there is a resounding dissonant chord ringing in my ear that will not resolve. I'm 20. I'm in college. I've got enough weight in my own life..I need a break from this semester to get ready for the next.
column20: I know that there comes a point when kids have to turn around and care for their parents. I just always invisioned that time being when I was married and had a family of my own and was used to caring for others like that. I expected it to come later when I would at least have the support of my spouse. But no, that time is now.&nbsp
column21: Thankfully my sister and my brother are gathering in to help which is amazing. If things work out like mom was thinking corey may be the one to spend the most time in Philly with her. :-) I'm really touched by that actually. I'm hoping that this might be a further catalyst for further growth in the relationship between my brother and I this Christmas. Holidays can be so difficult because at this point we only see each other maybe three times in a year and to be frank....we don't know each other. We know things about each other but we really don't know each other and it can be really ackward at times.&nbsp
column22: The wedding was a good weekend but it's still so superficial. I'm not sure yet how to fix it because we don't see each other.&nbsp
column23:
I'm really hoping that the stress from this break will create a stronger bond causing us to lean on each other and work together and not tear us futher apart.
I'm also really worried about my dad. He is staying home to continue working and holding down the fort. I know, whether he admits it or not, he doesn't want to be alone. That is kinda a hard weight to lay down. My parents and I have been having some growing pains before all this dealing with me growing up and what is expected when I come home on breaks. This adds a whole new level. I know there are going to be times when I need to go out and relax with my friends. There are also going to be times when I want to just stay home and spend time with dad. the tricky part is finding a balance everyone is at least okay with...preferably happy with too!!

Please don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to be overly selfish about all this. It's just I've spent alot of my life sacrificing my self too much for others and getting into sticky situations because of it. I've lost who I am more than I'd like to admit. This semester I've started on the track to fix that again and to be a little selfish but in a good way. In a way that takes care of myself so that I can be a benefit to others.
column24: Not to mention the weight of handling someone so close to you being so sick.&nbsp
column25:
Now that balance needs adjusted again and that's good, I just have to be careful to do it right and not too much to one side. There are things this break that I need for myself. There are things my family and friends need from me as well.

All in all things are good. My grades are much better again and after this coming semester I should be right on track as a true junior. I'll even get to spend a semester sitting in a true sophomore seat in chapel!! Yes!!

column10: So my classes this semester are:
column11: &nbsp
column12: Fitness Walking, Chapel, Social Psych, Handbells, (Gen Psych II), Latin, Philosophy, Math 120.&nbsp
column13: &nbsp
column14: I say I'm really taking 17 credits, and I put Gen Psych in parentesis because They are at the same time. column9: &nbsp

column11: Even though I was told I would have to have more than just that one surgery and I would never have good depth perception, that wasn't the case.&nbsp

column1: Monday June 19th, my mother and brother took her to Walmart and out to eat to celebrate her 83rd birthday. She was great! She was laughing and joking with them...having a great time.&nbsp
column2: That night she had horrible horrible stomach cramps. My parents stayed with her in the emergency room until after 1am. They got up at like 4am to take my brother back to the airport so he could catch his flight. Later that day my grandmother had surgery to repair a bowel obstruction. Thankfully they just had to unkink a part that had twisted. Because of her age they put her in the ICU on a ventilater. They told her as soon as she could breathe well enough on her own they would take it off. Mom said she looked really good. Wed. she took a small downward slope. They tried a couple times to take her off the vent but it wouldn't work. Thursday she slipped a little more. They had a priest (She was catholic) come in and he read her the last rites...no sooner had he said Amen, her blood pressure dropped into the single digits.
I was counseling at Wesley Woods all last week. I got a message about the surgery, and I had talked to my mom like wed. and she said everything was doing ok. Not perfect but not awful.&nbsp
column3: I got a call from her at 6am Friday morning saying the hospital had just called her and things weren't looking good. My plan was to stay at camp until lunch and then come home until dinner. I called my mom's cell phone at 10:15am to check in and tell her that and my daddy answered the phone sobbing. He choked out ""gramma's gone"" and I lost it. See my daddy doesn't weep very often. I've only seen him weep when his father died, and cried at the memorial service for his brother.&nbsp
column4: After she was read the last rites she just slowly drifted off in peace.&nbsp

column2: *sigh* My aunt came from Arizona on sunday, her boyfriend flew in last night, Corey and his girlfriend Kristy drove up from Kentucky on Saturday.&nbsp

column1: Last night was my final performance with the Erie Jr. Philharmonic. *tear* It was a little frustrating. We were playing three pieces for the Grand Opening of the Tom Ridge Evironmental Center in Erie. We were playing ""Presque Isle Celebration,"" a piece written for the Erie Jr. Phil. by a former member for the 50th Anniversary Celebration a few years ago, ""Hungarian March,"" which was one of the pieces I played my first day at Jr. Phil ( the first piece I had to transpose actually!! The funny thing was I got halfway through it the one week and kept forgetting week to week to finish it. So I'd be playing along and then lean over to see Leanna's music. I finally finished it though!!) and then ""Hoe-down"" (the ""beef it's what's for dinner"" commercial theme song.)  The only problem was, everyone in the ""Audience"" kept talking....most of them didn't make much of an effort to even try and be quiet. We were all arranged into an open area just inside the front doors. I'll admit it was quite a neat trick fitting almost 100 students in concert attire, chairs, stands, and instruments into the space they did. However all their talking made it difficult to hear and we got off in Presque Isle Celebration
column2: it was kind of a let down because it was such a great piece.   Oh well.   After the ""concert"" we had to turn in music and everyone but the seniors had to turn in their folders. event,"Hmm it's been awhile since I've posted...I'll give you a brief recap...

column1: event,"Ok Here I go...I'm going to try and put some pictures in here from my recent performances...I hope this works!!
This was after my spring Jr. Phil Concert in Edinboro. Gotta Love the Horn Grips!!
Me and My Kids!! Ben, Abbi, and Cammi.
The Jr. Phil Horns. Starting at the top Me, Leanna, Elise, Andrea, and Chelsea.
The String Quartet that played at Mercyhurst with me. Hilary, Elizabeth, Me, Carrie and Jonathan

Ok so Tuesday was the tour of schools with Jr. Phil. Amazing!! I woke up really late though..we were supposed to leave at 7:30am, I got up at 7:20!! My dad said he tried to wake me up, and my alarm went off..I just slept right through it. I really didn't feel well at all but I threw on my dress tossed up my hair and dashed to the car. I took a little nap on the way. Praise God we still made it before the bus got there!! So we played a concert in Cambridge Springs and then went to the Riverside Inn for lunch. oh Sorry I just had a song stuck in my head."" my reply ""Oh yeah? What song?"" Cory: ""Umm *thoughtfully* I don't remember""  Definitly one of the highlights!!
At lunch Mr. Dolwick asked if anyone could play at Mercyhurst College wed. night...they would pay. I jumped on it..sure man why not. We got handed the music before we left Girard.

Now I have to go get ready for the Jr. Phil Brass Ensemble concert tonight. *sigh* I've never played this much before!!! I mean a three hour rehearsal last saturday, a full concert Sunday, 45 min. in band on monday, two full concerts on tuesday plus practicing that night on my own, last night about four hours total between rehersal and then the concert, band today and now rehearsal and performance for ensembles!! I'm starting to go crazy!!!  But it is Oh so much Fun!!!

event,"Wow yesterday was soooo much fun!! My mom drove home sunday morning and went to church with my dad while I got ready for my concert. My hair still looked good from my night out at the coffee shop so I just straightend it and curled the ends again and clipped it back. It was amazing how well and easy it worked. (My hair does NOT cooperate!!) I found some of my old makeup and used that and it added a little bit more of a spark to the whole outfit...It was so much fun!! Mom and I drove together to Edinboro and dad followed. (a friend lent us her car for the weekend so everyone could get where they needed to be for all the different concerts and stuff. Man she's amazing....just handed over the keys. Wow.) Mom and I talked all the way about how the festival went. *Smiles* It was so nice to talk to her and her to share what God was doing. To talk more as friends...equals then ""mother daughter"". She even asked me to help her plan out the devotions for the weekend. God really used them in mighty ways too!! Hmm God is good.

I got to the auditorium right on time. I was greeted with a Senior Corsage. It was so pretty!! I wasn't expecting it either. I love it when that happens!  Actually, when I walked in I saw one of the other seniors with one and the thought went through my head that I wanted one, but it was prolly just something his mom did and I submitted my insecurities, my selfish desires back to God and humbled myself before him.....10 min. later one of the parents came over and gave me one. *smiles*

I had asked my mom to get flowers out of our garden for the other girls in my horn section. (I was thinking Daffidils or something...She came out with tiny purple pansies. At first I was disapointed and was afraid that it wouldn't be ""good enough"" But I went with it. Turns out mom picked excactly five, and all the girls liked them! Andrea and Chelsea put theirs over thier right ear...so the rest of us followed suit. It was so pretty!!
The concert itself went really really well. Everyone looked so classy
column2: the guys in Tuxs, and the girls in black. It was actually kinda funny to look around at the wide spread of girls outifts. From a black t-shirt, black jeans and sandels, to full out concert dresses.  We all played really well too. Personally i got a little jumpy on my entrances as the concert wore on, and Chelsea dropped her mute during Alladin. *rolls her eyes* I can't wait to hear the recording!!  Right before we played Alladin (the last piece) they recognized the seniors. They called each one by name and had them come to the front of the stage after greeting Mr. Dolwick and receiving a plaque. *amazed* It was brilliant!! It's a really pretty plaque too.

column1: After the concert we all had to sit on stage to take a group picture. Sounds harmless right...?  It took like a half an hour!!! Just sitting there. People were definitly getting restless!! When we were finally done we took Horn pictures. I love my section!! We just sat on the edge of the stage, let our feet dangle and held our horns...then they wanted to take a straight faced one...(HA) then we all crossed our legs in towards Chelsea and posed... then Andrea and Elise sat back to back. Chelsea jumped in front and Leanna and I went back to back behind...it was awesome!!

After those pictures were taken mom took me outside to try and take a ""senior"" pic for in my graduation announcments. Two out of the three might work. The other one was really good but right when she took the picture the wind blew some hair in my face. >_<.

OH yeah I forgot to mention that my sister and her family came too!! I was soooo happy!!! I knew they wanted to come but I didn't think they were going to make it. The kids were sooo good for the concert too. They have shown all along to be kinda musical but this was a big long concert...at least for marching band things they could have something to watch also. But they have been watching this tv show called ""Little Einsteins."" Basically each episode focuses on a famous classical piece and gets the kids used to it. They put cute little words to it sometimes and uses the song to accomplish some mission. Two of the like 6 pieces we played they knew. So they were sooo excited that they knew that song. (Hall of the Mountain King by Greig...from Peer Gynt, and The second movement of Davork's New World Symphony, more commonly known as Going Home. Plus I think they recognized Alladin too.) While they were all waiting to go outside Abbi was walking around the seats singing the melody to Going Home at like the top of her lungs...and she was hitting the notes right on!! She's Two!!!! It was wonderful!!  Mom said she was coloring during the concert and she would just stop and start directing with her crayon. And nodding her head or tapping her hands or feet to the beat. *Smiles* That's my girl!!

Once we finally left Edinboro mom and I took off again in the borrowed car and headed for Grove City Hoss's and dad went home. We had minor car trouble but got it fixed and went on our way again. We were going to Hoss's to meet up with all the bell ringers for dinner after their concert. I'm really glad we could do that. This way I felt like I was able to do it all. We were pretty crazy at dinner too!!  Everyone had a great weekend and really came together and bonded as a group away from the table. That is very important.   Last night when I came home I just sat outside in our back yard and relaxed in the night air. It was a beautiful night!!

Today has been a good day as well. In school today we played ""Ode to Joy"" to practice for graduation. I rocked it!! Playing so much this weekend really helped. It felt good to pick it up this year and nail the parts that I've struggled with the last couple years.  After band I went back to the doctors and told him that my throat is still bugging me, I still don't have any desire to eat, and I'm tired. Not like tired in the way that I want to sleep all the time, but It takes so much effort just to do what I need to do in a day. So he ordered a repeat mono spot and strep test, thyroid, and something he said was kinda like mono..but was like CMV? (Is that right Megan??) somethin like that anyways. So I go back next monday to see how I'm doing then. *sigh*  I left from the doctors and went to the hospital and had the blood work done, then met up with Karen for coffee.

We met at the coffee shop, and her daughter met up with us too at first. Then karen and I took our coffee and went for a walk down to Shiede Park and sat on a park bench and talked. It was really good. It really helped me realize how much I've changed since this retreat. That I am ok.  I was realizing this week that I know how to be the prodigal. I know how to to be broken and rebellious etc. etc. I even know how to be broken before God and come home. But much like Luke 15 my story seems to end there...during the party. I don't know how to live as this new creation. But I'm gettin there. I don't want to go back...I mean I do..but I won't. I'm finding Joy, I'm finding that the Joy of the Lord truly is my strength.  It's hard though I'm not going to lie. Already I've seen myself this week take little baby steps back toward the middle. But I'm staying on top of it. I'm reading the Word the first thing in my day, and the last thing in my day, even when I don't feel like it.  Jesus told a story of a man who had a demon cast out. The demon roamed around looking for someone else, but couldn't find anything so he went back to his guy and looked around. The man was swept clean...but empty. So the punk demon went and found like seven friends and reinhabited the man even worse then before. Pastor Dave posed a good question during a sermon. Whats the fastest and easiest way to get air out of a glass? A vaccuum would break the glass.....   Just fill it with water.  I'm clean now. I'm forgiven and free...but that's not the end of the story. Now comes the time of activly living out my faith. It's time for the renewing of my mind. It's about walking, not following, but walking hand in hand and filling the emptiness with Christ. If I ""feel"" like it or not. It's truth.  I still have authority issues. I still try to get my way in a situation... I need to work on that. I need to get back to submitting. See I didn't used to have authority issues. Man if there was  rule I followed it!! But I think when I became Drum major I did have a different set of rules to follow. Such I was in a place of leadership for so long, it is hard for me to be under authority. It was really really great though to part with Karen and have her say ""Sounds like you are doing well. Good Job, keep it up"" Instead of ""You'll get it kid... make a choice"" or a threat.  I am doing ok. We talked about college. I seriously can not wait for it. To be able to go and be in a group (hall) and be surrounded with People my age or older and just having fun doing things together...like going to the grill, playing cards...doing goofy stuff. Having a group to pray with and study with... Being able to let go compleatly of the strongholds here. (I can say that because I would have to choose to take them with me...I choose not to.)

After karen and I talked for like an hour and a half, I deposited my tax returns (YAY!!!!) and turned in my application to Pizza Hut. So we'll see what happens there. I don't know what to do about this summer. I really don't want to work. I want to be able to just be free to choose what I need to do in a day and be at the whim of everyone elses schedules. But i guess it's a good thing to work...seeing as how most people are going on mission trips during the summer. It will keep my hands and my mind from becoming idle....right?  OH! I got a call today from my old camp dean. He wants me to counsel for him in June. That would rock!! I love that camp. He said he needed my energy!! *giggles* I had so much fun doing that camp two years ago. That was my first time as a real counselor.  So maybe it will work out. But if I do that and ARC (which I haven't heard a thing about yet..) that's two weeks right there that I would have to take off work...:-/. Plus I really do want to go to St. Louis....*arghs* Don't know what to do!! So please pray that God would orchastrate my summer. I took the step to turn in the application..now it's up to him to make something or nothing out of it!!

event,"Wow today turned out to be a really good day. I had the ""dress rehearsal"" for my Jr. Phil concert today in Edinboro, stopped by my former voice teacher's house and payed the rest of my what I owed for lessons and got to talk to her for a sec...that was nice. I've missed her a bit. Then I was on my own. My dad is working a shift at the firestation, and my mom is with the bell choir so it's just the dog and I. I couldn't figure out what I wanted/needed to do....go be with people or be compleatly alone. I came home from rehearsal, got something to eat and just started watching Tv....It really wasn't cutting it and it was only like 2:30 in the afternoon. I really didn't want to read because of all the music I had played that morning, and I knew that If I took a nap I wouldn't sleep tonight. So I decided to message Brittney and see maybe what she was doing...if by same chance maybe she wanted to hang out or something. As it turns out the ""band"" that lead our worship at the retreat. (Elizabeth Hamm from Galloway..we go ""way"" back, Danette from New Mexico, and Tonga from India)were playing at a coffee house. (not the one that karen kinda owns.) So we decided to meet up and go. (YAY!!) So I cleaned up my 'partment a little and decided to actually make it a ""date"" and like do the hair, the make-up, the outfit...the ""special shower"" (you know girls..the one where we use the ""special"" shampoos, and body wash, and exfoliate....well you get the idea!) I really enjoyed the fact that I was getting ""prettied up"" for no other reason then that I wanted to. It wasn't for a guy, or a concert, or an interview...it was because I wanted too!!  It all worked really well I might add. (If I may say so myself!!) I wore my brown dress pants and my ""baby doll"" (man I'm using a lot of quotation marks and parentheses tonight!!) t-shirt that I got from ATF this year...baby blue with Dut. 4:20 (I think) scrolled on it. It has a couple green and a couple white flowery things on it...I relaly like it.  Hmm ya know details don't relaly matter do they?

It was a really nice time out. Grace (one of the girls that used to be in my Jr. High Uplinks) insisted on buying me coffee!! She's so sweet.  Brittney and and and uh-oh I forgot her name...Lori? Played a three person game of war. (with cards) I like beat them both by a lot!!  karen was there, we played chess. Don't ever play chess with a former math teacher. You lose...HARD!!  I tell you what...I don't think there is much that woman hasn't done!! She's crazy!
I was really excited though to see Danette and Tonga again. I thought they had to fly back when Nathan left. But they are here until May!!! Yippie!!

So yeah anyways...continuing with the trend of spoiling myself my face is covered in a green masque...and it is definitly dry...I can't move my face!! Oh. My. Goodness. It's definitly 3:19am!!! *laughs*"
